journal-article	0	10.3390/ma14237192	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156afef0>	journal-article:None	Effect of a Compound Energy Field with Temperature and Ultrasonic Vibration on the Material Properties and Bending Process of TC2 Titanium Alloy	<jats:p>Due to the low formability and forming quality of titanium alloy
column2: the forming process of a compound energy field (CEF) with temperature and ultrasonic vibration was proposed. Tensile tests were carried out to investigate the effect of the CEF on the true stress–strain curve
column3: yield strength
column4: elastic modulus
column5: and other mechanical properties of the TC2 titanium alloy. Bending tests assisted by CEF were also performed to investigate the effect of different parameters of the CEF on bending force
column6: spring-back
column7: bending fillet radius
column8: and microstructure of TC2 titanium. The results demonstrate that compared to the process under a single-temperature field
column9: the CEF can reduce yield strength
column14: which shows that the CEF can further increase the high-temperature softening effect of TC2 titanium. Furthermore
column15: this effect becomes more remarkable when ultrasonic vibration energy increases. As a result
column16: the formability of titanium alloy can be improved.</jats:p>	en	('vor'

column1: journal-article	1	10.1155/2022/7746374	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156aea50>	journal-article:None	Evaluation and Analysis of the Intervention Effect of Systematic Parent Training Based on Computational Intelligence on Child Autism	<jats:p>Autism
column2: also known as pervasive developmental disorder or autism spectrum disorder
column3: is a group of clinical syndromes of developmental delay or impairment. Social impairment
column4: verbal communication impairment
column5: and behavioral impairment are the three conditions for the diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder
column6: according to the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual. According to relevant statistics
column7: about 1 in 100 children is now diagnosed with autism
column8: and their rehabilitation treatment is also valued by people from all walks of life. In the rehabilitation training of autistic children
column9: it is found that the rehabilitation training of autistic children should pay attention to the role of parents and family environment. It is crucial that parents receive systematic training and act as partners in the development of the intervention plan. Research shows that a specific structured education and skills training program for parents of children with autism can be beneficial in improving behavioral problems
column11: and symptoms of autism in children with autism. To this end
column12: this paper has completed the following work: Secondly
column13: a portion of the systematic training of CA parents is discussed
column14: followed by an explanation of the structure and principles of BPNN. Finally
column15: the BPNN is utilized to create a model for assessing the impact of systematic parent instruction on CA. The experimental findings suggest that the proposed BPNN outperforms the competition.</jats:p>	en	('unspecified'

column1: journal-article	2	10.1093/geroni/igaa057.1126	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156afb30>	journal-article:None	A Systematic Review of Interventions That Reduce Family and Friend Caregiving Time	"<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>The decreasing number of family/friend caregivers available to help the rising number of older adults is creating a critical family care gap. For this reason
column2: there is a growing need for interventions that reduce family/friend caregiving time. We systematically reviewed five electronic databases to identify randomized trials
column3: case control
column4: quasi-experimental
column5: and cross-sectional studies that evaluated a modifiable element that could be targeted for interventions with care recipients 65+ and/or their family/friend caregivers and reported on an outcome of time spent caregiving. We excluded studies without a comparison
column6: broadly defined. The initial search included 1
column7: 812 unique records. Following abstract and title screening 311 full-texts were reviewed. Fifty-five studies published between the years of 1990 and 2019 met inclusion criteria. Studies predominantly focused on care recipients with dementia (58%) and were largely conducted in western countries (91%). The categories of interventions reviewed included pharmaceuticals (25%)
column16: with one study falling into multiple categories. Pharmaceuticals
column19: and multi-component interventions demonstrated promising evidence to reduce family/friend caregiving time. Methodologically
column20: studies were inconsistent in measurement and ascertainment of caregiving time. Given the public health concerns of reduced availability of family/friend caregivers for older persons in the upcoming decades
column21: caregiving interventions should consider measurements of caregiving time as key outcomes.</jats:p>"	en	('vor'

column1: journal-article	4	10.1126/sciadv.abh0496	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156adcd0>	journal-article:None	The transmembrane endoplasmic reticulum–associated E3 ubiquitin ligase TRIM13 restrains the pathogenic-DNA–triggered inflammatory response	"<jats:p>

The endoplasmic reticulum (ER)–localized stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is the core adaptor for the pathogenic-DNA–triggered innate response. Aberrant activation of STING causes autoinflammatory and autoimmune diseases
column2: raising the concern about how STING is finely tuned during innate response to pathogenic DNAs. Here
column3: we report that the transmembrane domain (TM)–containing ER-localized E3 ubiquitin ligase TRIM13 (tripartite motif containing 13) is required for restraining inflammatory response to pathogenic DNAs. TRIM13 deficiency enhances pathogenic-DNA–triggered inflammatory cytokine production
column4: inhibits DNA virus replication
column5: and causes age-related autoinflammation. Mechanistically
column6: TRIM13 interacts with STING via the TM and catalyzes Lys

column1: <jats:sup>6</jats:sup>
-linked polyubiquitination of STING
column2: leading to decelerated ER exit and accelerated ER-initiated degradation of STING. STING deficiency reverses the enhanced innate anti-DNA virus response in TRIM13 knockout mice. Our study delineates a potential strategy for controlling the homeostasis of STING by transmembrane ER-associated TRIM13 during the pathogenic-DNA–triggered inflammatory response.

column1: </jats:p>"	en	(None

column1: journal-article	5	10.1093/qjmed/hcae175.462	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ae870>	journal-article:None	Assessment of Serum Phospholipase D1 (PLD1) in Adult Patients with Newly Diagnosed Acute Myeloid Leukemia	"<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:sec>
<jats:title>Introduction</jats:title>
<jats:p>Phospholipase D (PLD) enzymes have been implicated in diverse cellular processes in cancer
column2: including the Warburg effect and pro-survival pathways. However
column3: the significance of PLD's role in tumorigenesis remains uncertain due to its genomic proximity to PI3Kinase-a
column4: which is amplified in various cancers. Additionally
column5: PLD signaling mechanisms are complex and context- dependent.</jats:p>

column1: </jats:sec>
<jats:sec>
<jats:title>Objective</jats:title>
<jats:p>This study aimed to assess the level of PLD1 in newly diagnosed acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients and its potential role as a prognostic indicator.</jats:p>
</jats:sec>
<jats:sec>
<jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
<jats:p>A case-control study was conducted on 30 newly diagnosed AML patients and 30 age and sex-matched healthy controls. Serum samples were collected
column2: and PLD1 levels were detected using ELISA. Correlations between PLD1 expression and clinical parameters were analyzed.</jats:p>

column1: </jats:sec>
<jats:sec>
<jats:title>Results</jats:title>
<jats:p>A statistically significant increase in PLD1 level was observed in AML patients compared to healthy controls (p &lt; 0.0001).while there is no correlation between pld1
column2: survival rate and other prognostic markers.</jats:p>

column1: </jats:sec>
<jats:sec>
<jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title>
<jats:p>The present study highlights the significant upregulation of PLD1 in AML patients and its association with specific FAB subtypes. While some clinical parameters showed correlations with PLD1
column2: its direct impact on survival remains uncertain
column3: warranting further investigation with larger sample sizes. This study contributes to the understanding of PLD1's role in cancer biology and its potential as a prognostic marker in AML.</jats:p>

column1: </jats:sec>"	en	('vor'

column11: error-prone manual processes. This system not only supports Kos Yani in daily operations but also has the potential to serve as a model for similar applications in the broader room rental sector. With the increasing demand for digitalization in Indonesia
column12: this system plays a critical role in accelerating digital transformation within the kos management sector
column13: contributing significantly to the development of more modern and structured property management. As a result

column1: journal-article	7	10.5210/spir.v2021i0.12143	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ad3d0>	journal-article:None	REJECTING SCIENCE WITH SCIENCE: BOUNDARY-WORK IN ANTI-MASK TWITTER REPLY        THREADS DURING COVID-19	<jats:p>The COVID-19 pandemic has been marked by a controversy in the United States over the public health benefits of mask-wearing
column2: especially on social media. Many have contested the scientific consensus that masks are an effective method to prevent and slow the spread of COVID-19 infections
column3: often along explicitly political lines. Here
column4: we investigate specifically how Twitter users engaging in arguments about mask-wearing invoke scientific principles to argue against masks. We further analyze the sources that these users cite to support their claims. Using a qualitative approach drawing from constructivist grounded theory
column5: we show how these users work to defend the legitimacy of their claims and their external sources by selectively exploiting rhetorical values of scientific endeavour. We analogize their work to the process of scientific boundary-work
column6: in which actors consciously manipulate the boundary between science and not-science for personal and political gain.</jats:p>	NA	(None
column7: None)	2	https://journals.uic.edu/ojs/index.php/spir/article/view/12143

column1: journal-article	8	10.26490/uncp.sl.2020.4.2.677	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156aec30>	journal-article:None	La imagen
column2: la cultura y la política en el proceso electoral extraordinario 2020 en Arequipa Perú	<jats:p>La investigación realizada examina el símbolo
column3: la cultura política
column4: así como la imagen de los candidatos y partidos políticos en el proceso electoral extraordinario al Congreso de la Republica
column5: realizado en enero del presente año en Perú; lo hace desde una perspectiva de la comunicación política. El objetivo es demostrar el nivel de articulación de los factores que construyen una sociedad democrática en un proceso electoral
column6: reconociendo que las relaciones entre cultura y política tienen larga data
column7: sin embargo

column9: siendo esa la razón fundamental del artículo. La metodología descriptiva aplicada combina técnicas de análisis de formatos de observación de la imagen con entrevistas Delphi
column10: generando resultados cuali-cuantitativos. Las conclusiones muestran una desarticulación de elementos concomitantes en la consolidación del orden político democrático

column12: la desideologización de las organizaciones políticas y el predominio de la imagen del “líder” sobre la del partido es una constante que debilita el fortalecimiento institucional de las organizaciones políticas.</jats:p>	NA	('unspecified'

column1: journal-article	9	10.3389/fbinf.2022.931583	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ae8d0>	journal-article:None	In silico approach to identify microsatellite candidate biomarkers to differentiate the biovar of Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis genomes	<jats:p><jats:italic>Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis</jats:italic> is the causative bacterial agent of the zoonotic disease known as caseous lymphadenitis
column2: and it presents several mechanisms of response to host defenses
column3: including the presence of virulence factors (VFs). The genomes of these bacteria have several polymorphic markers known as microsatellites
column4: or simple sequence repeats (SSRs)
column5: that can be used to characterize the genome
column6: to study possible polymorphisms existing among strains
column7: and to verify the effects of such polymorphic markers in coding regions and regions associated with VFs. In this study
column8: several SSRs were identified within coding regions throughout the 54 genomes of this species
column9: revealing possible polymorphisms associated with coding regions that could be used as strain-specific or serotype-specific identifiers of <jats:italic>C. pseudotuberculosis</jats:italic>. The similarities associated with SSRs amongst the different serum variants of <jats:italic>C. pseudotuberculosis</jats:italic>
column12: and it was possible to identify SSRs located in coding regions responsible for a VF enrolled in pathogenesis known to mediate bacterial adherence (SpaH-type pili virulence factor). Phylogenetic analyses revealed that strains sharing SSR patterns
column13: including the possible polymorphisms identified in the same position of gene-coding regions
column14: were displayed by strains with a common ancestor
column15: corroborating with the Genome Tree Report of the NCBI. Statistical analysis showed that the microsatellite groups belonging to <jats:italic>equi</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>ovis</jats:italic> biovars have a significance of 0.006 (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>-value) in similarity
column16: thus indicating them as good biomarker candidates for <jats:italic>C. pseudotuberculosis</jats:italic>.</jats:p>	NA	('vor'

column1: proceedings-article	7	10.1115/gt2024-128901	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ad790>	proceedings-article:None	Artificial Intelligence-Based Performance Maps for Expander-Compressor Analysis in Energy Transition Applications	"<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>Limiting the global warming impact requires a drastic reduction of greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) to reach a zero-carbon growth by 2050. Against this backdrop
column2: turbomachinery designers are asked to develop more compact
column3: efficient
column4: and reliable machines. The research focuses on developing machines able to reduce energy losses and overall footprint
column5: thus improving power plants efficiency and operability. To this end
column6: expander-compressors (EC) seem to play a key role in the energy transition and appear a promising technology for high-density plants
column7: especially together with hydrogen (H2) or supercritical carbon dioxide (sCO2) as working fluid. However
column9: a reduction in machine efficiency may be expected
column10: with a consequent degradation of the overall system performance. In order to optimize the operation of the power plant
column11: it is crucial to understand how the variation of the expander-compressor behavior affects the working conditions of the other components of the plant. In this perspective
column12: a fast and reliable way to estimate the EC performance at different operating conditions is necessary. Although the scientific literature shows several studies on mean-line approaches for expanders and centrifugal compressors
column13: the joint use of 1D models with artificial neural networks (ANN) for ECs combined machine is still overlooked. To fill this gap
column14: the prediction of artificial intelligence (AI)-based performance maps is proposed in this work. The tool has been tested in a case study based on a real EC. Results showed a rapid evaluation of EC efficiency while varying the operating conditions.</jats:p>"	NA	('vor'

column1: proceedings-article	8	10.5327/1980-5764.rpda056	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ad670>	proceedings-article:None	COGNITIVE ASSESSMENT OF ADULTS AND ELDERLY IN RECIFE-PE	<jats:p>Background: Currently
column2: the influence of schooling on the assessment parameters of cognitive tests is under debate. Objectives: Evaluate the performance of possessors in the MMSE (Mini-mental State Examination) and MoCA (Montreal Cognitive Assessment)
column3: evaluating the influence of education on the performance of the participants. Methods: This is a cross-sectional
column4: descriptive study with 33 participants without cognitive complaints. These were people aged 40 years or more
column5: and at least four years of schooling. Data were formed in SPSS (v.23)
column6: using Spearman’s correlation coefficient (CS). Results: The population is predominantly composed of women (87.8%)
column7: with a mean age of 58 years (SD = ± 9.5)
column8: and education of 11.7 years (SD = ± 4.2 years). The median performance on the MMSE was 25 points (95%CI = 24.5-26.4) and
column10: 75.8% had a value equal to or greater than 24 points. At the same time
column11: the median score in the MoCA was 20 points (95%CI = 18.6-21.7) and 18.2% of those evaluated scored equal to or greater than 26 points. As for the influence of education
column12: there was a correlation for both tools (MMSE: CS = 0.457; p = 0.008; MoCA: CS = 0.556; p = 0.001). Regarding age
column13: there was a correlation with MMSE performance (CS = 0.368; p = 0.035). Conclusion: MoCA and MEEM are correlated with the length of formal education. Thus
column14: it is important to consider this factor when interpreting these scales.</jats:p>	NA	(None

column1: proceedings-article	9	10.1115/gt2020-14302	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ae750>	proceedings-article:None	Behavior of a Variable Geometry Turbine Wheel to High Cycle Fatigue	"<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>Maximization of the turbocharger efficiency is fundamental to the reduction of the internal combustion engine back-pressure. Specifically
column2: in turbochargers with a variable geometry turbine (VGT)
column3: energy losses can be induced by the aerodynamic profile of both the nozzle vanes and the turbine blades. Although appropriate considerations on material limits and structural performance of the turbine wheel are monitored in the design and aero-mechanical optimization phases
column4: in these stages
column5: fatigue phenomena might be ignored. Fatigue occurrence in VGT wheels can be categorized into low and high cycle behaviors. The former would be induced by the change in turbine rotational speed in time
column6: while the latter would be caused by the interaction between the aerodynamic excitation and blades resonating modes.</jats:p>

column1: <jats:p>In this paper
column2: an optimized turbine stage
column3: including unique nozzle vanes design and turbine blades profile
column4: has been assessed for high cycle fatigue (HCF) behavior. To estimate the robustness of the turbine wheel under several powertrain operations
column5: a procedure to evaluate HCF behavior has been developed. Specifically
column6: the HCF procedure tries to identify the possible resonances between the turbine blades frequency of vibrations and the excitation order induced by the number of variable vanes. Moreover
column7: the method evaluates the turbine design robustness by checking the stress levels in the component against the limits imposed by the Goodman law of the material selected for the turbine wheel. In conclusion
column8: both the VGT design and the HCF approach are experimentally assessed.</jats:p>"	NA	('vor'

column1: book-chapter	0	10.1075/clcc.17.10kum	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ad850>	book-chapter:None	Portrait of the child as a socialist	"<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>This chapter focuses on portraits of children in three photographic picturebooks from the German Democratic Republic
(GDR). While these picturebooks draw largely on modernist photography in the postwar period
column2: they also react sensitively to

column1: ideological demands from the official state authorities. To demonstrate this influence
column2: this chapter exemplifies that these photobooks

column1: represent different aesthetic and ideological strategies. While <jats:italic>Bullermax</jats:italic> (<jats:xref>1964</jats:xref>) by Edith Rimkus and Horst Beseler is an exemplar of a poetic strategy and <jats:italic>Matti im Wald</jats:italic> (Matti in the
Forest
column2: <jats:xref>1966</jats:xref>) by the same couple represents a realistic strategy
column3: <jats:italic>Kleiner Bruder

column1: Staunemann</jats:italic> (Little Brother Marveling Man
column2: <jats:xref>1966</jats:xref>) by Hans Hüttner and Lotti Ortner

column1: stands for a propagandistic strategy. The chapter analyzes the inherent socialist values of the three books by stressing the idea of
the curious socialist child and the effects of montage.</jats:p>"	en	(None

column1: book-chapter	2	10.1215/9781478027485-003	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156adaf0>	book-chapter:None	The Antihero	<jats:p>This chapter explores the delicate balance between life as death and death as life through Kendrick Lamar's album DAMN. The imagery is rich: lack of lucidity or awareness is absence of something vital
column2: and this results in demise. And there is no safeguard. The chapter argues that all the action (that is
column3: life) taking place within the various lyrical narratives offered on the album is consumed by the specter of death. The chapter positions Lamar as an antihero whose challenge to the illusion of the distinction of life versus death is positioned against the heroic view expressed in Eminem's “Stan.” The latter is an effort to pretend that heroism is a safeguard for life
column4: rendering it distinctive.</jats:p>	en	(None

column1: book-chapter	3	10.4018/978-1-6684-3710-0.ch035	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ad610>	book-chapter:None	Game-Based Learning to Engage Students With Physics and Astronomy Using a Board Game	<jats:p>In this research article
column2: the authors developed a novel astronomy board game and examined how this approach could facilitate the learning and teaching of astronomy topics covered in the new Irish Science Syllabus. A total of 119 post-primary students took part in the pilot trial across Ireland. Data was collected via feedback questionnaires
column3: systematic observations and pre and post-test surveys. Results indicate that this astronomy board game significantly enhances students' knowledge of astronomy concepts and perceptions of scientists. Furthermore
column4: teachers showed positive attitudes towards this approach for teaching astronomy. Additionally
column5: the game was demonstrated as a useful learning tool and as an activity to promote social skills. The findings offer a promising basis for further exploration of the integration of game-based approaches to physics education to promote active participation and interaction
column6: balancing the learning objectives with play. </jats:p>	NA	(None

column1: book-chapter	4	10.4018/978-1-6684-3542-7.ch030	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ad490>	book-chapter:None	Using Ethnographic Approaches to Co-Construct Strategies for Success With Students With Dyslexia	<jats:p>This chapter takes a dual focus/lens to applying and performing research methods in inclusive and special education in a tertiary/post-secondary setting with a group of students with dyslexia. It links the core ideas of United Nations Convention on the rights of persons with disabilities Article 24
column2: Inclusive Education to describing the development and implementation of a co-constructed
column3: collaborative project to identify success strategies for students with dyslexia
column4: utilizing both student and teacher perspectives and experiences
column5: and examines the fit of utilizing ethnographic approaches in this. As practitioner –researchers
column6: authors provide a narrative case study of a project which was developed/co-constructed to respond to a set of identified needs for a group of students presenting with dyslexia. Authors then examine how the project practices link to research methodology
column7: particularly ethnography
column8: and produce both a set of strategies to work inclusively in the future with students with dyslexia and also construct a methodological approach within the lens of new ethnography. This serves to theories both the project work and guidelines for future use of ethnographic approaches for research in the field of inclusive and special education. </jats:p>	NA	(None

column1: book-chapter	6	10.1093/law/9780198849155.003.0065	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x1156ad5b0>	book-chapter:None	North America	"<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>This chapter assesses international environmental law in the courts of North America. In particular
column2: it explores the minimal engagement of US
column3: Canadian
column4: and Mexican courts with international environmental law. Environmental law cases in Canada
column5: Mexico
column6: and the United States are not immune to international law and international norms. However
column7: international environmental lawyers may be forced to look to some unlikely and unusual places to find international environmental law's normative influence. Environmental law cases in North America seem poised to engage most significantly with international law not in the ‘bright lights’ but rather on the side-lines
column8: where environmental law norms interface with climate law

Chapter 11 examines the role that international politics and international relations play in how the US approaches national security and military space policy. Drawing from the theories of realism
column2: liberalism
column3: and constructivism
column4: it highlights the varying conceptions of how the space domain should and is utilized by the United States. It ends with a consideration of the major policy challenges in the near future including the rise of China

column6:
and possible policy responses.

column1: book-chapter	9	10.1063/9780735425514_023	<crossref_api.Crossref_REST_API object at 0x115348d10>	book-chapter:None	Toward More Rapid Accumulation of Knowledge about What Works in Physics Education: The Role of Replication
column2: Reporting Practices
column3: and Meta-Analysis	<jats:p>This chapter examines the literature on interventions in physics education through the lens of optimizing and accelerating knowledge accumulation. Specifically
column4: intervention research in physics education is discussed in terms of the prevalence of randomized designs and meta-analyses of effects from similar interventions. The authors make several recommendations to the physics education research community
column5: citing calls from within and outside of physics education for more rigorous designs
column6: more comprehensive and transparent study reporting practices
column7: and increased efforts to synthesize intervention research. The call for improved reporting practices is framed in the need for supporting replication studies
column10: with an acknowledgement of the challenges related to direct replication and the affordances of conceptual replications for theory-building. Included in the chapter are suggestions for how entities such as funding agencies
column12: and evidence clearinghouses can facilitate knowledge accumulation by incentivizing and supporting more rigorous primary intervention studies
column13: as well as replications and syntheses thereof.</jats:p>	en	(None
